name: Pima County Coordinating Agencies for Housing and Services
description: A comprehensive directory of agencies and organizations providing housing assistance, shelter, and support services for individuals experiencing homelessness in Pima County, including resources accessible to Ajo residents.
eligibility: Individuals experiencing homelessness or at risk of homelessness in Pima County
contactInfo: Multiple agencies with varying contact information - See website for complete listing
notes: Resources include Arizona 211, Old Pueblo Community Services, Our Family Services, Center of Opportunity, Salvation Army, Pio Decimo Center, CODAC, La Frontera Arizona RAPP, Primavera Foundation, and Tucson Pima Collaboration to End Homelessness. While most services are based in Tucson, they serve the entire county including Ajo.

name: Pima County Homeless Services Division
description: A county-wide service division that provides support for individuals and families experiencing homelessness or at risk of homelessness, including outreach, prevention, emergency shelter, and housing assistance.
eligibility: Individuals and families experiencing homelessness or at risk of homelessness in Pima County
contactInfo: Phone: 520-724-7300 (Monday through Friday, 8 a.m. to 5 p.m.) | Sullivan Jackson Employment Center
notes: While there are no homeless services located specifically within Anegam city limits, residents can access county-wide services through the Pima County Homeless Services Division, which operates out of the Sullivan Jackson Employment Center and has served homeless households since 1989.

name: Pima County Office of Housing Opportunities and Homeless Solutions
description: A county-wide service division that provides centralized information and coordination of services for individuals and families experiencing homelessness or at risk of homelessness in Pima County, including Marana residents.
hours: Monday through Friday, 8 a.m. to 5 p.m.
eligibility: Individuals and families experiencing homelessness or at risk of homelessness in Pima County, including Marana residents
application_process: Call the Pima County Homeless Services Division at 520-724-7300 for assistance

name: Arizona Department of Economic Security Homeless Services
description: A state agency that coordinates homeless services through federal and state funds, contracting with nonprofit and local government entities to provide rapid rehousing, emergency shelter, homeless prevention, and street outreach services throughout Arizona.
eligibility: Individuals and families experiencing a housing crisis in Arizona
application_process: Call 211 or visit the 2-1-1 Arizona website to obtain assistance with locating shelter, affordable housing, and limited rent and utility assistance

name: Pima Find a Ride
description: A directory of transportation services for the general public, people with disabilities, and older adults who need access to reliable transportation in the greater Tucson region, including South Tucson.
address: 1 E. Broadway Blvd., Suite 401, Tucson, AZ 85701
eligibility: General public, people with disabilities, and older adults in the greater Tucson region
application_process: Contact through phone or website
service_area: South Tucson and greater Tucson region

name: Pima Council on Aging
description: Pima Council on Aging (PCOA) is a nonprofit organization that provides resources, services, and advocacy for older adults in Pima County, helping them age with dignity and independence.
address: 600 S. Country Club Road, Tucson, AZ 85716
eligibility: Older adults in Pima County, primarily those 60+
application_process: Contact directly for specific program requirements

name: Child & Family Resources
description: Nonprofit organization providing support services for children and families in Pima County
eligibility: Families with children in Pima County
application_process: Contact directly through phone or website

name: Control Alt Delete
description: Nonprofit organization helping domestic violence victims flee abuse in Arizona
services: Basic necessities for victims fleeing abuse
eligibility: Domestic violence victims in Arizona
application_process: Contact through website

name: International Rescue Committee (IRC)
description: Nonprofit organization providing services for refugees, immigrants, and vulnerable populations
services: Support for victims of human trafficking
eligibility: Refugees, immigrants, victims of human trafficking, and other vulnerable populations
application_process: Contact through website or phone
service_area: Arizona, primarily Phoenix area but services extend to surrounding areas including Pimaco_Two
target_group: Refugees, immigrants, victims of human trafficking

name: Primavera Foundation
description: Primavera Foundation co-creates tangible pathways out of poverty with individuals and families. They focus on the root causes of poverty and homelessness and partner with community members to overcome barriers to safe, affordable, permanent housing.

name: Tucson Pima Collaboration to End Homelessness
services: Coordinates homeless services across Pima County
Provides resources and referrals for homeless individuals
Operates coordinated entry system for housing assistance
description: TPCH is a coalition of community and faith-based organizations, government entities, businesses, and individuals committed to ending homelessness in Tucson and Pima County. They coordinate services, provide resources, and work to develop solutions to homelessness throughout the region.

name: Youth On Their Own
description: Youth On Their Own (YOTO) supports the high school graduation and continued success of youth experiencing homelessness in Pima County. They strive to eliminate barriers to education and empower housing insecure youth to stay in school by providing financial assistance, basic human needs, guidance, and more.

name: Bread & Roses Crisis Transitional Shelter For Homeless LGBTQ+ Youth
description: A transitional shelter program providing housing and support services for homeless young adults who identify as LGBTQ+, including case management and services that lead to self-sufficiency.
eligibility: Youth age 18-24 who identify as lesbian, gay, bisexual, transgender, queer, or questioning
contactInfo: Emerson Kuhn | Phone: (520) 547-6109 | Email: ekuhn@saaf.org | Address: 375 S. Euclid Ave., Tucson, AZ 85719-6644
notes: Program is operated by the Southern Arizona AIDS Foundation (SAAF) and serves LGBTQ+ youth throughout Pima County, including residents of Ak Chin.

name: Tucson Pima Collaboration to End Homelessness (TPCH)
description: A county-wide resource directory and coordination system for homeless services in Pima County, providing access to emergency shelter, housing assessments, and support services for individuals experiencing homelessness.
eligibility: Individuals and families experiencing homelessness or at risk of homelessness in Pima County
notes: While there are no homeless shelters located within Ali Chuk city limits, residents can access services through the Tucson Pima Collaboration to End Homelessness (TPCH), which coordinates homeless services throughout Pima County. The resource directory provides information on shelter beds, housing programs, and support services.
languageSupport: English, Spanish, and translation services available

name: Emerge Center Against Domestic Abuse
description: The largest provider of comprehensive domestic abuse services and programs in Southern Arizona, offering court advocacy, crisis intervention, safety planning, and support services for victims of domestic violence.
eligibility: All individuals experiencing domestic abuse regardless of age, income, ethnicity, gender, sex, sexual orientation, sexual expression, ability, religion, national origin, or immigration status
contactInfo: Hotline (24/7): 520-795-4266 or 1-888-428-0101 | Community-based services: 520-881-7201 (Mon-Fri 8:30AM-5:00PM) | City Court Advocate: 520-837-3012 (Mon-Fri 8:00AM-4:30PM)
notes: Emerge delivers confidential, trauma-informed services via court advocates who help survivors navigate the criminal justice system, offer information about rights and options, provide emotional support, accompany survivors to court proceedings, and assist with orders of protection and safety planning. Services are available to residents throughout Pima County, including Ali Chukson.

name: Sullivan Jackson Employment Center (Pima County)
description: A county-wide employment center that helps individuals experiencing homelessness find employment and housing opportunities through job training, resume assistance, and employment placement services.
eligibility: Individuals experiencing homelessness in Pima County
notes: While there are no homeless services located specifically within Ali Molina city limits, residents can access county-wide services through the Sullivan Jackson Employment Center, which provides employment assistance and housing support for individuals experiencing homelessness throughout Pima County.

name: Pima County LGBTQIA+ Community Resources
description: A comprehensive directory of organizations, support services, and resources for LGBTQIA+ individuals in Pima County, including services accessible to Casas Adobes residents.
eligibility: LGBTQIA+ individuals and allies in Pima County
contactInfo: Multiple organizations with varying contact information - See website for complete listing
notes: Resources include Anti-Violence Project (AVP), Southern Arizona AIDS Foundation, Arizona Queer Archives, EON Youth Lounge, Equality Arizona, Family Pride Initiative, and many other organizations providing support, healthcare, crisis services, and community connections for LGBTQIA+ individuals throughout Pima County including Casas Adobes.

name: Catalina Foothills School District McKinney-Vento Program
description: A comprehensive support program for homeless children and youth in the Catalina Foothills School District, providing educational stability and resources for students experiencing homelessness.
eligibility: School-age children and youth who lack a fixed, regular, and adequate nighttime residence due to loss of housing, economic hardship, or similar reason
contactInfo: Dr. Erin Matyjasik | Phone: 520-209-8081 | Special Services Department
notes: Services include school enrollment assistance, transportation to school of origin, automatic enrollment in free lunch program, and connection to additional support services. The program follows the federal McKinney-Vento Homeless Education Act to ensure educational stability for homeless students.

name: Pima County Homeless Services for Catalina
description: While there are no homeless shelters located within Catalina city limits, residents can access homeless services and shelters in nearby Tucson and throughout Pima County.
eligibility: Individuals experiencing homelessness or at risk of homelessness in Catalina and Pima County
contactInfo: For assistance, contact Arizona 211 or visit the Pima County Coordinating Agencies for Housing and Services website
notes: Nearby resources include Primavera Men's Shelter, The Salvation Army Hospitality House, and The Primavera Foundation Shelter for families, all located in Tucson. Catalina residents must travel to access these services as there are no local shelters within city limits.

name: DomesticShelters.org Resource Directory
description: A comprehensive online directory that helps domestic violence victims find local shelters, programs, and support services throughout Pima County and nationwide. The service provides searchable listings of shelters and programs based on location.
eligibility: Individuals experiencing domestic violence or abuse
contactInfo: Website: https://www.domesticshelters.org/ | National Domestic Violence Hotline: 1-800-799-7233
notes: While there are no domestic violence services located specifically within Chiawuli Tak city limits, residents can access county-wide and national services through DomesticShelters.org, which provides a searchable database of shelters and programs. The Arizona DES domestic violence resources were inaccessible at the time of processing due to website access issues.
languageSupport: English, Spanish, and multiple other languages through hotline services

name: Poverello House of Tucson
description: Poverello House of Tucson is a nonprofit organization providing a homelike place of welcome and a safe environment with daytime rest, food, laundry facilities, showers, and companionship for men and women experiencing homelessness.
hours: By reservation only, limited to 10 guests per day
eligibility: Adults experiencing homelessness
application_process: Call (520) 637-8916 to reserve a space
service_area: Tucson and surrounding areas including Corona de Tucson
contactInfo: Phone: (520) 637-8916 | Address: Tucson, AZ (specific address not publicly listed for security)
serviceArea: Tucson metropolitan area (including Corona de Tucson)
notes: While there are no homeless services located specifically within Corona de Tucson city limits, residents can access services in nearby Tucson. Poverello House requires advance reservation due to limited capacity (10 guests per day).

name: Arizona DES Homeless Services for Drexel Heights
description: State-level homeless services and resources available to Drexel Heights residents through the Arizona Department of Economic Security, including rapid rehousing, emergency shelter, homeless prevention, and street outreach programs.
eligibility: Individuals experiencing homelessness or at risk of homelessness in Drexel Heights and Pima County
contactInfo: Call 211 for assistance or visit the Arizona DES website
notes: While there are no homeless shelters located within Drexel Heights city limits, residents can access services through the DES Homeless Coordination Office and Pima County resources. The DES collaborates with Continuums of Care (CoC) to ensure needs are assessed and addressed throughout Arizona.
languageSupport: English, Spanish, and multiple other languages through translation services

name: The Lighthouse Project
description: Provides LGBTQ+ affirming and trauma-informed supportive services for individuals experiencing housing instability. The program offers links to permanent supportive housing, case management, and other support services.
eligibility: Individuals who identify as LGBTQ+ experiencing housing instability
contactInfo: 1037 E. 34th St., Tucson, AZ 85713 | Phone: (520) 909-0754 | Case management: Monday-Friday | Intake: Wednesday
notes: While there are no homeless services located specifically within Gu Oidak city limits, residents can access this county-wide service that provides specialized support for LGBTQ+ individuals experiencing housing instability.
languageSupport: English, Spanish services may be available

name: Rescued Helpers
description: A non-profit organization serving as a lifeline for those in need, offering a range of services and resources to uplift and empower individuals facing various challenges, including those experiencing homelessness.
eligibility: Individuals in need in the Tucson area
contactInfo: 1325 W Kleindale Rd, Tucson, AZ 85705 | Phone: +1 (520) 888-7377
website: http://rescuedhelpers.com (Note: Website was inaccessible at time of verification)
notes: This organization is physically located in Kleindale. Limited information is available as the website was inaccessible at time of verification. MapQuest description indicates they provide shelter and educational programs for those in need.

name: Greater Littletown Human Resources Group
description: A local community organization providing resources and support services to individuals experiencing homelessness and other vulnerable populations in the Littletown area.
eligibility: Residents of Littletown and surrounding areas in need of assistance
notes: This organization is specifically mentioned in the Tucson Arizona Homeless Shelters & Services resource list as serving the Littletown area. Limited information is available about specific programs offered.

name: The Primavera Foundation
description: Provides comprehensive emergency shelter and support services for individuals experiencing homelessness, including men's shelter, women's shelter (Casa Paloma), family shelter (Family Pathways), veteran services, transitional housing, and drop-in services at their Resource Center.
eligibility: Individuals and families experiencing homelessness in Pima County; specific programs have specific eligibility requirements
contactInfo: Resource Center: 702 S. 6th Ave, Tucson, AZ 85701 | Phone: 520-623-5111
notes: While there are no homeless services located specifically within Littletown city limits, residents can access this county-wide service. The Resource Center is open Mondays, Wednesdays, Thursdays, and Fridays from 9 a.m. to 12:30 p.m. (closed Tuesdays, weekends, and holidays).

name: City of Tucson Housing First Program
description: A comprehensive program that provides street outreach, emergency shelter, housing navigation, and supportive housing services for individuals and families experiencing homelessness in Pima County, including Nolic residents.
address: 310 N Commerce Park Loop, Tucson, AZ 85745
eligibility: Individuals and families experiencing homelessness in Pima County, including Nolic residents
application_process: Access through street outreach teams or contact the Housing & Community Development Department directly

name: Tohono O'odham Nation Child Care Services
description: An early care and education service provider serving low-income families in the Tohono O'odham Nation, including Pisinemo, with child care centers and various provider options for children from 6 months through age 12.
eligibility: Low-income families with children from 6 months through age 12 in the Tohono O'odham Nation
application_process: Visit the 'How to Apply' section on their website

name: Kino Veterans' Workforce Center
description: A comprehensive support center for veterans that provides employment assistance, training, benefits counseling, and other essential services to help veterans and their families in Pima County, including Rillito residents.
eligibility: Veterans and their families in Pima County, including Rillito residents
application_process: Call 520-724-2646 or visit the center

name: Family Resource Center at Sahuarita Food Bank
description: A community resource center that provides family support programs, educational activities, and food assistance for families in Sahuarita. Offers programs like Preschool Play for ages 3-5, Fun Family Fitness, and Nature Play activities.
eligibility: Families with children in the Sahuarita area
application_process: Contact via phone or email, or attend scheduled events

name: Valley Assistance Services
description: A nonprofit organization providing assistance for housing, utilities, financial education, and workforce training for families and seniors in the Sahuarita and Green Valley region, in addition to other health and safety programs.
address: 3950 S. Camino del Heroe, Green Valley, AZ 85614
eligibility: Families and seniors in the Sahuarita and Green Valley region
application_process: Call to make an appointment: 520-625-5966
service_area: Sahuarita and Green Valley region (Pima County)

name: Pima County Youth Health Hub
description: A resource navigation tool designed to assist youth and young adults (ages 24 and under) and their parents/caregivers in finding community resources tailored to their needs. The program connects youth with health, wellness, and safety resources throughout Pima County.
eligibility: Youth and young adults ages 24 and under, and their parents/caregivers. Anyone under 13 must have parent's permission.
application_process: Select from categories of services on the website, select age, and receive a list of age-appropriate resources. For additional help, fill out the Health Services Family Referral Form.

name: Clinica Amistad
description: A free clinic offering medical services to those who are unemployed or uninsured in South Tucson and surrounding areas. Staffed by volunteers and providers who speak Spanish, making healthcare accessible to the Spanish-speaking community.
eligibility: Unemployed or uninsured individuals in South Tucson and surrounding areas
application_process: Contact directly or visit in person

name: Tucson Clinica Medica Familiar
description: A medical clinic providing healthcare services to families in South Tucson, with a focus on serving the Spanish-speaking community and providing culturally competent care.
eligibility: All residents, with focus on Spanish-speaking families
application_process: Contact through phone or visit in person

name: El Rio Health Center (El Pueblo, Summit)
description: A community health center providing comprehensive healthcare services to residents of South Tucson and surrounding areas, with a focus on accessible and affordable care for underserved populations.
address: 101 W. Irvington Rd., building 10, Tucson, AZ 85714
eligibility: All residents, with sliding fee scale for uninsured and low-income patients
application_process: Contact through phone or visit in person

name: Pima Council on Aging (PCOA) Transportation Services
description: Provides resources on transportation programs and volunteer services for the elderly in South Tucson and surrounding areas. Various organizations offer door-to-door rides by volunteers in the community.
eligibility: Elderly residents in South Tucson and surrounding areas
application_process: Contact through phone or website

name: VA Medical Center - Southern Arizona Health Care
description: A comprehensive medical center providing healthcare services to veterans in South Tucson and surrounding areas, offering primary care, specialty services, mental health care, and other veteran-specific health programs.
eligibility: Veterans enrolled in VA healthcare system
application_process: Contact through phone or website, or visit in person

name: Green Spirits Healing Veterans Retreat
description: A healing retreat program for veterans in Three Points that helps them overcome mental health issues like PTSD and depression. The program includes building raised garden beds, plant therapy, animal connection therapy, yoga, massage therapy, and group discussions with mental health professionals.
eligibility: Veterans experiencing mental health issues
application_process: Contact through VFW Post 10254

name: Three Points Veterans Memorial Park
description: A community park honoring veterans that features baseball fields, a basketball court, playground with shade structure, picnic tables, and ramadas available for reservation. The park serves as both a recreational facility and a memorial to veterans in the Three Points area.
eligibility: Open to the public
application_process: Ramada reservations can be made through the website

name: VFW Post 10254
description: A Veterans of Foreign Wars post serving veterans and the community in Three Points. The post organizes events like Day of Service, supports veteran-owned businesses, provides health services, and runs programs like the Warriors Garden Program in partnership with Green Spirits Healing.
eligibility: Veterans of foreign wars and their families
application_process: Contact through phone or website

name: Caridad Community Kitchen
description: Caridad Community Kitchen provides hot meals to individuals experiencing food insecurity in Tucson. They serve meals Monday through Friday from 2:00 PM to 4:00 PM.
eligibility: Open to the public, no ID required
application_process: Walk-in during serving hours

name: HSL Center of Opportunity
description: The HSL Center of Opportunity is a collaborative homeless shelter campus in Tucson that brings together over 30 nonprofit organizations to provide comprehensive services for people experiencing homelessness. The center offers a range of services including shelter, healthcare, workforce development, and support for the journey out of homelessness.
address: 4550 S Palo Verde Rd, Tucson, AZ 85714
eligibility: Individuals experiencing homelessness in Tucson and Pima County
application_process: Visit the center or contact partner organizations for specific program requirements

name: Community Food Bank of Southern Arizona
description: The Community Food Bank of Southern Arizona provides food assistance, prepared meals, and emergency groceries to individuals and families in need throughout Tucson and Pima County. They offer an interactive map to find food resources by zip code or cross streets.
address: 2411 E Ft Lowell Rd, Tucson, AZ 85719
hours: Tuesday: 1:00 PM - 4:00 PM, Wednesday: 1:00 PM - 4:00 PM, Thursday: 1:00 AM - 4:00 PM
eligibility: Individuals and families in need of food assistance in Tucson and Pima County
application_process: Visit during open hours or use interactive map to find nearest location

name: Department of Economic Security - Tucson
description: The Arizona Department of Economic Security (DES) is a partner organization at the Center of Opportunity in Tucson, providing government benefits, veterans assistance, and support services for individuals experiencing homelessness. They are part of the collaborative campus approach to addressing homelessness holistically.
address: 4550 S. Palo Verde Rd., Tucson, AZ 85714
eligibility: Individuals experiencing homelessness and other vulnerable populations in Tucson and Pima County
application_process: Visit the Center of Opportunity campus or contact directly

name: El Rio Community Health Center
description: El Rio Community Health Center is a partner organization at the Center of Opportunity in Tucson, providing comprehensive healthcare services to individuals experiencing homelessness and other vulnerable populations. They offer medical, dental, and mental health care as part of the collaborative campus approach to addressing homelessness.
address: 4550 S. Palo Verde Rd., Tucson, AZ 85714
eligibility: Individuals experiencing homelessness and other vulnerable populations in Tucson and Pima County
application_process: Visit the Center of Opportunity campus or contact directly

name: Gospel Rescue Mission
description: Gospel Rescue Mission provides comprehensive services for individuals experiencing homelessness in Tucson, including emergency shelter, recovery programs, employment assistance, housing support, and outreach services. They are located at the Center of Opportunity, a collaborative campus with over 30 partner organizations.
address: 4550 S. Palo Verde Rd., Tucson, AZ 85714
eligibility: Individuals experiencing homelessness in Tucson and Pima County
application_process: Contact directly or visit the Center of Opportunity campus

name: His Presence Church Arizona
description: His Presence Church Arizona provides hot meals to individuals experiencing food insecurity in Tucson. They serve meals on the 2nd and 4th Fridays of each month.
eligibility: Open to the public, no ID required
application_process: Walk-in during serving hours

name: Holy Family Church
description: Holy Family Church provides hot meals to individuals experiencing food insecurity in Tucson. They serve meals on Sunday afternoons.
eligibility: Open to the public, no ID required
application_process: Walk-in during serving hours

name: La Frontera Arizona
description: La Frontera Arizona is a partner organization at the Center of Opportunity in Tucson, providing behavioral health services, substance abuse treatment, and mental health support for individuals experiencing homelessness and other vulnerable populations. They are part of the collaborative campus approach to addressing homelessness holistically.
address: 4550 S. Palo Verde Rd., Tucson, AZ 85714
eligibility: Individuals experiencing homelessness and other vulnerable populations in Tucson and Pima County
application_process: Visit the Center of Opportunity campus or contact directly

name: Northminster Presbyterian Church
description: Northminster Presbyterian Church provides hot meals to individuals experiencing food insecurity in Tucson. They serve dinner on Monday evenings.
eligibility: Open to the public, no ID required
application_process: Walk-in during serving hours

name: Tucson Pima Collaboration to End Homelessness (TPCH) Coordinated Entry
description: Coordinated Entry is the first step for people experiencing homelessness to obtain housing in Tucson and Pima County. TPCH provides shelter referrals, hot meal locations, eviction prevention assistance, and coordinates homeless services through their Coordinated Entry System.
eligibility: Individuals and families experiencing or at risk of homelessness in Tucson and Pima County
application_process: Contact through website, email, or visit in person

name: Z-Mansion
description: Z-Mansion provides grab & go meals for individuals experiencing food insecurity in Tucson. They serve breakfast on Sunday mornings.
eligibility: Open to the public, no ID required
application_process: Walk-in during serving hours

name: Greater Vail Community ReSources
description: Greater Vail Community ReSources is a 501(c)(3) Arizona nonprofit organization that provides emergency food assistance to families in need, meals for the home-bound, and supplemental weekend food bags for students in the Vail, Corona de Tucson, and Southeast Tucson areas.
services: Weekend "Meals to Grow" bags for students
eligibility: Residents in need in the Vail, Corona de Tucson, Rita Ranch, and Southeast Tucson areas
application_process: Contact through website or visit during distribution hours
service_area: Vail, Corona de Tucson, Rita Ranch, and Southeast Tucson

name: Haven Totes
description: Haven Totes is a 100% volunteer-run nonprofit organization that provides food assistance to low-income families with children in Tucson area schools, serving over 1,000 families annually.
services: Weekend food bags for school children
eligibility: Families of children in the schools served by Haven Totes
application_process: Contact through website or school referral
service_area: Tucson area including Corona de Tucson

name: National Community Health Partners
description: National Community Health Partners is a nonprofit organization that provides mental health support, peer-led groups, and suicide prevention services for veterans and their families in Pima County.
services: Best Is Yet to Come program
eligibility: Veterans and their families in Pima County
application_process: Contact through website or phone
service_area: Pima County including Corona de Tucson

name: Youth on the Rise
description: Youth on the Rise (YOTR) is a resource platform developed to help youth and young adults navigate services, resources, and information in Pima County, providing guidance on education, employment, housing, health services, and more.
eligibility: Youth and young adults in Pima County
application_process: Access through website

name: Nexus Teen Academy
description: Nexus Teen Academy is a nonprofit organization providing residential treatment programs for teens struggling with mental health challenges, behavioral issues, and substance abuse in the Tucson area.
eligibility: Teens struggling with mental health challenges, behavioral issues, and substance abuse
application_process: Contact through website or phone
target_group: Youth & At-Risk Teens, Substance Abuse Recovery

name: El Rio Health
description: A community health center providing comprehensive healthcare services to the Tucson area, including specialized care for LGBTQ+ individuals with transgender health services and HIV/AIDS treatment.
services: Fresh produce distributions (in partnership with Community Food Bank)
eligibility: Open to all residents of Tucson and surrounding areas
application_process: Contact directly to schedule an appointment
service_area: Tucson and surrounding areas including Flowing Wells
target_group: General population with specialized services for LGBTQ+ individuals

name: Tohono O'odham Nation
description: The official tribal government of the Tohono O'odham Nation, providing services and programs to tribal members in Gu Oidak and other communities within the reservation.
eligibility: Tohono O'odham tribal members
application_process: Varies by program; contact directly
service_area: Tohono O'odham Nation reservation including Gu Oidak
target_group: Tohono O'odham tribal members and communities

name: Pima Council on Aging (PCOA)
description: Pima County's leading experts on aging well, advocacy, and unbiased information for older people and their families. Founded in 1967, PCOA was among the first aging services organizations in the nation.
eligibility: Older adults in Pima County, including Kleindale area
application_process: Contact directly via helpline or visit website

name: Primavera Foundation
description: The Primavera Foundation provides emergency shelter and services to individuals experiencing homelessness in Pima County, with a mission to provide pathways out of poverty.
phone: Not specified on emergency services page
email: Not specified on emergency services page
services: Casa Paloma (women's shelter, hospitality center and day shelter)
eligibility: Individuals and families experiencing homelessness in Pima County
application_process: Contact directly or through outreach services

name: Youth On Their Own (YOTO)
description: Youth On Their Own supports the high school graduation and continued success of youth experiencing homelessness in Pima County, striving to eliminate barriers to education and empower housing insecure youth to stay in school.
address: 2525 N Country Club Rd, Tucson, AZ 85716
eligibility: Youth experiencing homelessness in Pima County
application_process: Contact directly or through school referral

name: Youth on the Rise (YOTR)
description: Resource navigation and support organization for youth in Pima County
eligibility: Youth in Pima County
application_process: Contact through website

name: Picture Rocks Community Center
description: A community center that provides youth and teen programs with discounted rates for low-income families, including after-school programs, summer recreation, and teen leadership opportunities.
hours: Varies by program; After-School Program: School dismissal until 6 p.m.; Summer Programs: Monday-Thursday, 7:30 a.m.-5:00 p.m.
eligibility: Children ages 5-12 for after-school program; K-5th grade for summer recreation; 6th-9th grade for teen leadership; Low-income families eligible for discounted rates with proof of qualification (SNAP, Free/reduced school lunch, TANF, AHCCCS, Section 8)
application_process: Online registration or call 520-724-5000 for available spaces

name: Rillito Center
description: A specialized education facility for students with high needs from preschool to age 22, providing special education services, assistive technology, and individualized learning experiences to help students reach their highest potential and develop independence.
eligibility: Students with special education needs from preschool to age 22
application_process: Contact Amphitheater Public Schools Special Education Department

name: Disabled American Veterans (DAV) Chapter 38
description: A veterans service organization that helps veterans navigate the VA disability claims process, securing benefits for approximately 600 area veterans. They provide free assistance with disability claims and connect veterans with healthcare resources.
address: Sahuarita Food Bank and Resource Center, Sahuarita, AZ
eligibility: Veterans in the Sahuarita and Green Valley area
application_process: Contact via email at arizonadav38@gmail.com or visit their office at the Sahuarita Food Bank and Resource Center
service_area: Sahuarita and Green Valley region (Pima County)

name: San Miguel Resource Center
description: A crisis center providing support for survivors of domestic violence and sexual assault. Services include 24-hour crisis intervention, emergency shelter, counseling, legal advocacy, and personal assistance for basic needs.
eligibility: Survivors of domestic violence and sexual assault
application_process: Call the 24-hour helpline at 844-816-3915 or contact the main office

name: Santa Rosa Homelessness Solutions
description: A city program that provides comprehensive services to address homelessness, including shelter, housing assistance, and support services. The program works through partnerships with County agencies and community organizations to implement both immediate and long-term strategies.
eligibility: Individuals experiencing homelessness or at risk of becoming homeless in Santa Rosa area
application_process: Contact via email at homeless@srcity.org or call 707-543-3311

name: Santa Rosa Junior College Student Resource Centers
description: A college-based resource center that provides support for students, staff, and faculty experiencing homelessness or housing insecurity. Services include shower access, hygiene supplies, emergency food, coordinated entry interviews, and referrals to housing resources.
address: Santa Rosa Campus, Santa Rosa Junior College
hours: Virtual Walk-in Hours: Mondays & Thursdays: 9am-1pm, Tuesdays & Wednesdays: 12pm-4pm
eligibility: Santa Rosa Junior College students, staff, and faculty experiencing homelessness or housing insecurity
application_process: Virtual/video appointments or phone appointments available; email or call to schedule

name: Tohono O'odham Nation Komckud Ki: Domestic and Sexual Violence Prevention Program
description: A tribal program providing emergency shelter, 24/7 hotline, and comprehensive services for victims of domestic and sexual violence in the Tohono O'odham Nation. Services include emergency assistance, legal support, housing services, and community education.
eligibility: Victims of domestic and sexual violence in the Tohono O'odham Nation and surrounding areas
application_process: Contact via 24/7 hotline at 866-666-4889 or admin line at 520-383-6000
service_area: Sells, AZ and Tohono O'odham Nation

name: International Rescue Committee (IRC) - Phoenix/Tucson
description: A nonprofit organization providing comprehensive case management in the areas of social, legal, employment, psychiatric & medical services for immigrants and refugees. They help clients rebuild their lives and achieve financial stability through various programs.
address: Multiple locations in Phoenix and Tucson
eligibility: Immigrants and refugees in Arizona
application_process: Contact by phone or through website for program-specific information
service_area: Phoenix, Tucson, and surrounding areas in Arizona

name: Pima County Public Library - Teen 365 Program
description: A library-based program that helps teens explore, create, collaborate, and succeed through makerspaces, online tools, in-person classes, and various resources.
address: Multiple library locations throughout Pima County
phone: Not specified on website for specific program
services: Youth Health Action Team focused on mental health
eligibility: Teens and tweens (ages 9-18)
application_process: Visit any Pima County Public Library location

name: Southern Arizona Senior Pride

name: Family Housing Resources
description: Family Housing Resources (FHR) is a nonprofit service organization dedicated to building a community with equal access to quality affordable housing and pathways to increased wealth and financial freedom.
